thread.title: Bradley Cooper cooks up enthusiasm for role as chef in `Burnt'
thread.title_full: Bradley Cooper cooks up enthusiasm for role as chef in `Burnt' | Boston Herald

author: Stephen Schaefer
title: Bradley Cooper cooks up enthusiasm for role as chef in `Burnt'
text:
Bradley Cooper cooks up enthusiasm for role as chef in `Burnt' Stephen Schaefer Monday, October 26, 2015 SEEKING STARS: In ‘Burnt,’ Bradley Cooper plays a chef hoping to rebuild his reputation by earning three Michelin stars for his restaurant. comments Tweet NEW YORK — For Bradley Cooper, playing a chef in “Burnt” was like a step back in time.
“When I was a kid, I was a prep cook at a seafood restaurant in Somers Point, New Jersey,” he said.
One skill he learned there — shucking oysters — came in handy on his very first day of filming in London.
He’d learned, “If you’re ever going to slice your hand, it’s shucking an oyster,” and so he warned director John Wells, “Bro, just to let you know, if this goes south it’s going to be two or three weeks (for my hand to heal) and I hope you have a lot of other stuff to shoot.
“That’s because,” he added, “no doubles were used in the movie.”
All the chopping, slicing, dicing and shucking captured on camera was really done by a cast that trained for weeks in various high-end Michelin-starred London restaurants.
Since they were cooking and eating real food throughout the weeks of filming, most cast members worried about putting on weight. But not Cooper.
“I was in the process of losing 40 pounds,” the “American Sniper” star explained, to appear onstage in “The Elephant Man.” “It was kind of a nightmare.”
In “Burnt,” Cooper plays Adam Jones, a world-famous chef fresh from rehab and eager to regain his reputation by nabbing the highest possible honor any restaurant can achieve: three Michelin stars.
But troubled by rages and outbursts leveled at his staff, Adam is perpetually on edge.
“I did a tremendous amount of research and speaking to people in that world, and I think the movie is actually pretty tame,” Cooper, 40, said at the London Hotel.
“Adam is all self-loathing. When he’s screaming (at everyone), he’s really screaming at himself.
“I could relate to his obsession to do the best he can. But more than any other character I’ve played, I saw how different we are.
“Because he’s lost the joy in what he did.
“That’s a hell of a thing to lose. Food is so joyful, and he’s lost joy in cooking, which is where he is for so much of the movie.”
(“Burnt” opens Friday.)
